newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel, Klima reaffirm committment to EMU.
newsitem.headline: Waigel, Klima reaffirm committment to EMU.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel and Austrian Chancellor Viktor Klima on Wednesday reaffirmed the commitment of each of their countries to qualify for European economic and monetary union (EMU).

Speaking to reporters after a meeting, Waigel said the timetable for monetary union was not as important as fulfilling the fiscal goals and Klima said the treaty left room to interpret a nation's performance.
"I have always said that the convergence criteria will determine the timetable," Waigel told reporters.
Klima, during his first official visit to Germany as Chancellor, said there was room in the Maastricht Treaty to interpret a country's performance and whether it had fulfilled the fiscal targets.
He said he was opposed to renegotiating the Maastricht Treaty but added, "we should use the room available in the treaty to interpret the criteria."

Germany, among the most outspoken advocates of a strict interpretation of the treaty, itself runs a high risk of not meeting the Maastricht limits on budget deficits this year, by which European Union members will be assessed for EMU.

Germany must fight rising unemployment and boost growth to meet the targets, Waigel said, adding "if we are successful in getting unemployment down by the beginning of the summer, we can fulfill the criteria."
